title: Bayesian Computations
text:
In this page, you can find teaching materials, examples, case studies and information related to the Bayesian Computations module of the PhD course in Bayesian statistics.
I gently acknowledge Tommaso Rigon, who has initially developed the material of this module. The previous version of the module material is available at the following link
https://tommasorigon.github.io/CompStat/
All credits goes to him, all mistakes are mine.

title: Bayesian Computations
text:
Prerequisites
It is assumed the knowledge of the following topics:

Fundamentals of Bayesian statistics. Refer to Chapters 1-5 of Hoff (2009).
Monte Carlo integration. Refer to Chapter 3 of Robert and Casella (2009), or Chapter 4 of Hoff (2009).

Main references

Blei, D. M., Kucukelbirb A., and McAuliffe, J. D. (2017). Variational inference: a review for statisticians. Journal of the American Statistical Association, 112(518), 859–877.
Chopin, N. and Ridgway, J. (2017). Leave Pima indians alone: binary regression as a benchmark for Bayesian computation. Statistical Science, 32(1), 64–87.
Durante, D. and Rigon, T. (2019). Conditionally conjugate mean-field variational Bayes for logistic models. Statistical Science, 34(3), 472–485.
Eddelbuettel, D. and Balamuta, J. J. (2018). Extending R with C++: a brief introduction to Rcpp. The American Statistician, 72(1), 28–36.
Hunter, D. R., and Lange, K. (2004). A Tutorial on MM Algorithms. The American Statistician, 58(1), 30–37.
Neal, R. M. (2011). MCMC using Hamiltonian dynamics. CRC press.
Polson, N. G., Scott, J. G. and Windle J. (2013). Bayesian inference for logistic models using Pólya–Gamma latent variables. Journal of the American Statistical Association, 108(504), 1339–1349.
Roberts, G. O. and Rosenthal, J. S. (2001). Optimal scaling for various Metropolis-Hastings algorithms. Statistical Science, 16(4), 351–367.
Roberts, G. O. and Rosenthal, J. S. (2009). Examples of adaptive MCMC. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, 18(2), 349–367.
